correct_answers.explanation: /etc/shadow stores encrypted user passwords
chsh command allows modifying a user's default shell
Primary GID is indicated in /etc/passwd file
UID 0 corresponds to the root user
Login shell is the program launched after login
passwd command allows a user to change their password
who | wc -l counts the number of connected users
By default, a user's primary group is identical to their UID
tree command displays directory tree structure
fg command brings a process to the foreground
& symbol allows launching a process in the background
If a background process reads from STDIN, it gets suspended
ps command displays processes of the current shell
su command allows becoming root (sudo -i also works but su is standard)
chmod u+x adds execute permission to the owner
~/.bashrc is executed when opening a bash interactive non-login shell
ip route displays the IP routing table (modern command, though route and netstat -r also work)
renice command modifies the priority of an existing process
Ctrl+C sends SIGINT signal
nohup allows a process to continue after disconnection
tar command is used to archive files
df command displays disk space usage
All options (poweroff, halt, shutdown now) can shut down the system immediately
Devices are located in /dev directory
cp command copies files and directories
zcat command reads compressed files
uname -r displays the kernel version
script command records a session
stty command configures the terminal
uname command displays the OS name
All options (exit, quit, logout) are correct ways to quit a session
cat /etc/passwd displays the contents of /etc/passwd file
echo $SHELL displays the current shell
tcsh command temporarily launches tcsh shell
mkdir monRep creates a directory named monRep
touch f1 f2 creates two files in one command
id command displays UID and GID
mv command is used to move files
ls command displays the content of the current directory
rmdir command deletes an empty directory
mv command is used to rename files
find command searches for files by name (locate also works but find is more standard)
find . -name core -exec rm {}; deletes all core files
man find displays help for the find command
ln -s creates a symbolic link
$PATH variable contains the path of executable commands
Both diff and cmp commands allow comparing two text files
alias ll='ls -l' is the correct syntax to define an alias
echo command displays a message
groups command displays the groups to which the current user belongs
PS1 variable defines the primary prompt
umask command modifies the default permissions mask
chgrp command allows changing the owning group of a file
alias rm='rm -i' creates an alias for confirmation deletion
ps -me displays the current user's processes
nom(){} is the standard syntax to declare a function in shell
read command reads user input
&& is the logical AND operator in shell scripts
echo command displays a result
history command displays the command history
